questions.text: A patient who had undergone electro-convulsive therapy presented to the casualty with pain over the shoulder. The arm was held in internal rotation and could not be rotated back to the normal position. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient has a posterior shoulder dislocation, which is characterized by the arm being held in internal rotation and an inability to externally rotate the arm back to its normal position. This condition can frequently occur after an electric shock or convulsion.

  • Posterior Shoulder Dislocation: The AP radiograph typically shows an overlapping of the humeral head on the glenoid.
  • Clinical Features: The arm is held in internal rotation and adducted, with pain and difficulty in moving the arm. The patient may appear comfortable in a "sling" position.
  • Radiographic Findings:
    • AP View: Displays an "electric bulb sign" due to the medial rotation of the humeral head, and an "empty glenoid sign" where the humeral head is positioned posterior to the glenoid.
    • Recommended Views: An axillary view or CT scan is often recommended for better evaluation.

Mechanism of Injury:

  • Typically results from a direct blow to the anterior aspect of the shoulder or injury with the shoulder in internal rotation, adduction, and flexion.

Incorrect Options:

  1. Adhesive Capsulitis (Frozen Shoulder): This is characterized by shoulder stiffness and pain due to inflammation, not by a dislocation
  2. Calcific Tendinitis: Involves calcium deposits in a tendon, causing localized pain, not a dislocation.
  3. Anterior Shoulder Dislocation: The arm is in an abducted and externally rotated position, opposite to what is described in this case.

Reference: Miller's Review of Orthopaedics, 8th Edition, Page 796.

questions.text: A 35 year old female was admitted to a hospital with fracture shaft of femur. After 2 days, she developed breathlessness and altered sensorium. Despite aggressive resuscitation efforts, she passed away three hours later in the intensive care unit. The autopsy finding in the lung tissue is shown below. What is the probable cause of death?
questions.solution:
• Image shows fat globules in lung tissues which is suggestive of fat embolism.
  • The fat globules may originate from bone marrow or adipose tissue. Fat embolism is more common following severe injuries with multiple fractures and fractures of major bones like femur, pelvis and tibia.
  • Symptom Triad of fat embolism: (i)cerebral; (ii) pulmonaryand (iii) petechial rashes
  • In the cerebral type,the patient becomes drowsy, restless and disoriented and gradually goes into a state of coma.
  • In the pulmonary type,tachypnea and tachycardia are the more prominent features.
  • The other common feature of fat embolism is a petechial rash, usually on the front of the neck, anterior axillary folds, chest or conjunctiva. If untreated, and sometimes despite treatment, the patient develops respiratory failure and dies.

Other options:

  • Crush syndrome - This syndrome results from massive crushing of the muscles, commonly associated with crush injuries sustained during earthquakes, air raids, mining and other such accidents.
  • Causes: Crushing of muscles results in entry of myohaemoglobin into the circulation, which precipitates in renal tubules, leading to acute renal tubular necrosis.
  • Consequences: Acute tubular necrosis produces signs of deficient renal functions such as scanty urine, apathy, restlessness and delirium. It may take 2-3 days for these features to appear.
  • Cardiogenic shock and pneumonia don't show this type of histology on biopsy images.

Reference: Maheshwari 5th edition, chapter 7, page no 44

choices.text: External fixation with serial doppler examinations
Open reduction internal fixation using plates and screws

questions.text: 25-year-old male presented to the casualty with fracture both bones of right leg after a RTA. He was splinted in the field, but on arrival to the emergency room, he complains of painful "tightness" around the leg and severe uncontrolled pain despite maximum dose analgesics. His pain is exacerbated when the toes and ankle are passively dorsiflexed. What is the most appropriate next step in treatment?
questions.solution:
• This patient has clinical symptoms and signs of leg compartment syndromeand should undergo immediate fasciotomy followed by external fixation for fracture stabilization.
  • Tibial fractures are among the most common reasons for compartment syndromes of the leg. A clinical assessment is key in the diagnosis of acute compartment syndrome. If there is uncertainty, intracompartmental pressure measurement has been advocated to help confirm the diagnosis.
  • 6 p's of compartment syndrome:pain out of proportion to injury paralysis, paresthesias, pallor, pulselessness and pain on passive stretch.
  • We cannot perform intramedullary nailing or open reduction and internal fixation in this case because surgery itself is a predisposing factor for development of compartment syndrome

Reference: Maheshwari ortho 5th edition, page number 47.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because she has pain in the right arm two hours after she fell in her home. Physical examination shows swelling and deformity of the right arm. The patient is unable to dorsiflex the wrist. X-ray studies show a spiral mid-shaft fracture of the humerus. Which of the following nerves is most likely affected by this fracture?
questions.solution:
• This clinical vignette describes the classical wrist drop occurring in association of humerus fractures due to injury to Radial N.
  • The radial nerve courses posterior to the middle third of the humeral shaft and is prone to injury with fractures of the midshaft of the humerus. Sensory distribution of the radial nerve includes the first dorsal web space of the hand, and motor innervation includes the dorsal forearm extensor muscles, including those of the wrist.
  • Radial N involvement is more common in distal third humerus fractures, and such fractures associated with Radial N injury is called Holstein Lewis fracture.
  • Option (A)- Axillary, is incorrect because this nerve is located posterior to the humeral neck. It provides sensation over the deltoid region and innervates the deltoid muscle.
  • Option (B)- Median, is incorrect because this nerve courses through the medial aspect of the arm between the biceps brachii and brachialis muscles. It provides sensation to the radial aspect of the palm and fingers as well as the distal dorsal surfaces of the thumb, index finger, long finger, and the radial aspect of the ring finger. Motor innervation within the hand includes the muscles of the thenar eminence.
  • Option (C)- Musculocutaneous, is incorrect because this nerve does not innervate any muscles involved in motor function of the wrist or hand.

Reference: Maheshwari Ortho 5th edition, page no 63

questions.text: According to Salter-Harris classification, which type of physeal fractures is shown on this x-ray (lateral view) of the right ankle?
questions.solution:
• This x-ray demonstrates a fracture through the posterior aspect of tibial metaphysis, extending to the growth-plate which appears disrupted. The triangular metaphyseal fragment is known as the Thurston Holland fragment which indicates that a type 2 Salter-Harris fracture has occurred.
  • Type II is by far the most common and has a good prognosis.

Reference: https://radiopaedia.org/articles/salter-harris-classification?lang=us

questions.text: A 23 year old lady has recently delivered a baby and is now complaining of pain in her left wrist for 1 month. O/E there is tenderness over the radial styloid and Finkelstein test is positive. Which structures are affected?
questions.solution:
• Positive Finkelstein test is seen in De quervain tenosynovitis.
  • De quervain tenosynovitis is the tenosynovitis of the 1st dorsal compartment. And the tendons of the 1st dorsal compartment are APL and EPB which will be inflamed.
  • Symptoms - Pain over the wrist and base of thumb
  • Signs - Tenderness over radial styloid and Finkelstein test +ve
  • Finkelstein test
    • Patient is asked to clench the fist with thumb inside the palm.
    • Then the wrist is ulnar deviated causing pain
  • Treatment
    • Thumb spica splint
    • Steroid injection
    • Surgical release of 1st dorsal compartment


Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page no. 303

questions.text: A 40-year-old male sustained a fracture in his right knee as shown in the figure. What would be the treatment of choice in this fracture?
questions.solution:
• The x ray shows a displaced transverse fracture of patella, which is treated using Tension band wiring.
  • Patella fractures are managed based on the fracture pattern.
    • Undisplaced fractures - cylinder cast.
    • Displaced transverse fractures - tension band wiring.
    • Comminuted fractures - patellectomy.
  • Osteochondral fracture

Reference: Essential Orthopaedics: Maheshwari & Mhaskar, 5th Edition, Page Number-147.

choices.text: Tried correcting equinus before heel varus
Used below knee casts instead of above knee casts

questions.text: A 3-month-old patient with clubfoot who you've been treating with the Ponseti Method has returned to your clinic. On examination, the foot appears as it does in Figure A. What treatment error has been made?
questions.solution:
• Rocker bottom foot deformity occurs when equinus is corrected before heel varus and forefoot pronation.
  • Congenital clubfoot, or talipes equinovarus, consists of four main parts: midfoot cavus, metatarsus adductus, varus hindfoot, and equinus contracture. The goal of manipulation is to rotate the foot around a fixed talus. This must be done in the order described by Ponseti.
  • The mnemonic C-A-V-Eis an easy method to remember the order of treatment (Cavus, metatarus Adductus, Varus, Equinus). If equinus is addressed before the cavus and varus hindfoot, dorsiflexion occurs through the midfoot instead of treating the hindfoot equinus, thus creating a rockerbottom foot.
  • Answer A: Under-correction of foot pronation can lead to residual cavus deformity
  • Answer B: Over correction of metatarsus adductus would lead to an abduction deformity of the forefoot.
  • Answer D: Below knee casts are not considered sufficient immobilization to fully take advantage of the manipulations you perform

Reference: MAHESHWARI ORTHO 5TH EDITION PAGE NO 214.

questions.text: Identify the implant shown in the image
questions.solution:
• The image shows a ring external fixator applied on a patient's leg.
  • This is called Ilizarov fixator.
  • Ilizarov fixator works on the principle of distraction osteogenesis.
  • Uses of Ilizarov fixator
    • Fixation of open fractures
    • Primary fixation of complex closed fractures
    • Infected non unions
    • Gap non unions (bone transport)
    • Deformity corrections
    • Limb lengthening

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page no. 33

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis of the condition in the image below?
questions.solution:
In the X ray, Shenton's line is broken and the acetabulum is empty, hence the hip is dislocated. Now the difficulty is to identify whether the dislocation is anterior or posterior. These can be differentiated only by looking at the deformity of the limb. In anterior hip dislocation, the deformity is flexion, abdution, external rotation and in posterior dislocation, its flexion, adduction, internal rotation. In this x ray, the femur is adducted, hence it is posterior dislocation of hip.


Reference: Maheshwari ortho 5thedition, page no 130

questions.text: 60 year old patient presents to the OPD with pain in several joints of the hand. On examination, there is features of arthritis in PIP, DIP and 1st CMC joint. However, the wrist is spared. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Reference: Maheshwari ortho 5th edition page no 295

questions.text: You are asked to see a 70-year-old woman with a swollen right knee that is warm and tender. You perform an arthrocentesis and observe positively birefringent, rhomboid-shaped crystals on polarized microscopy. The gram stain shows no organisms, and the synovial fluid culture grows no organisms. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Pseudogout is caused by calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate crystals, which are positively birefringent on polarized microscopy.
  • Pseudogout most commonly affects the knee and, unlike gout, is more common in women than men. Polyarticular gout and pseudogout may mimic rheumatoid arthritis.
  • The lack of symmetry, prolonged morning stiffness, positive serologies, and systemic symptoms may help differentiate polyarticular crystal arthropathy from rheumatoid arthritis.

Reference: Essential Orthopaedics: Maheshwari & Mhaskar, 5th Edition, Page Number-293.

questions.text: A 60 year old man with chronic renal failure presents with back pain. His x-ray is shown above. What is the characteristic finding seen in the x ray?
questions.solution:
• RUGGER JERSY SPINE is seen in RENAL OSTEODYSTROPHY
    • Renal osteodystrophy is characterized by bone mineralization deficiency due to the electrolyte and endocrine abnormalities associated with chronic kidney disease.
    • The pathogenesis of renal osteodystrophy is multifactorial.
    • Hypocalcemia occurs due to the inability of the damaged kidney to convert vitamin D3 into its active form, calcitriol.
    • The hypocalcemia and lack of phosphate excretion by the damaged kidney causes hyperparathyroidism and secondary hyperphosphatemia.
  • DDs of rugger jersey spine are given below.

    • Reference: Maheshwari, Essential Ortho, 4th edition, Page no. 315.

questions.text: A 65 year old female presented to the OPD with complaints of back pain for the last 2 years. X-ray of her lumbar spine is given below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• X-ray shows codfish/biconcave vertebra which is seen in osteoporosis.
  • Osteoporosis is a condition characterized by reduction in bone mineral density. Here all the biochemical parameters will be normal only the quantity of bone tissue diminishes throughout the body.
  • Loss of bone mass leads to loss of strength so that a trivial trauma is sufficient to cause a fracture.
  • Dorso-lumbar spine is the most frequent site or pathological fracture in osteoporosis.

RADIOLOGICAL FEATURES

Radiological evidence of decreased bone mass is more reliable, but about 30 per cent of the bone mass must be lost before it becomes apparent on X-rays. Following features may be noticed on X-rays:

  • Loss of vertical height of a vertebra due to collapse.
  • Cod fish appearance: The disc bulges into the adjacent vertebral bodies so that the disc becomes biconvex.

Reference: Maheshwari Ortho, 5th edition, Page no. 309.

questions.text: A 3 year old child presented to the OPD with deformities of lower limb. On examination, there is thickening of the lower end of long bones. X-ray taken is given above. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above x-ray shows the classical findings od splaying, cupping and fraying of metaphysis, seen in rickets.

RADIOLOGICAL SIGNS OF RICKETS:

  • Delayed appearance of epiphyses.
  • Widening of the epiphyseal plates(earliest change)
  • Cupping of the metaphysis
  • Splaying of the metaphysis
  • Fraying of the metaphysis
  • Rarefaction of the diaphyseal cortex occurs late.
  • Bone deformities: Bow legs(bilateral genu varum) is the most common deformity seen in rickets.

Reference: Maheshwari ortho, 5th edition, Page no. 311.

choices.text: Rupture of the medial collateral ligament, damage to the medial meniscus, and rupture of the anterior cruciate ligament
Rupture of the Lateral collateral ligament, damage to the medial meniscus, and rupture of the anterior cruciate ligament
Rupture of the lateral collateral ligament, damage to the lateral meniscus, and rupture of the anterior cruciate ligament
Rupture of the medial collateral ligament, damage to the medial meniscus, and rupture of the posterior cruciate ligament

questions.text: Unhappy triad of O'Donoghue is?
questions.solution:
• The unhappy triad was described by American orthopedic surgeon D H O'Donoghue, in 1950.
  • He described simultaneous occurrence of tear of ACL, MCL and medial meniscus tear when lateral force applied to knee while the foot is fixed to the ground.

Reference: Manish Kumar Varshney 1st edition page no 889.

choices.text: En bloc excision with structural allograft reconstruction
En bloc excision with wrist fusion using vascularized fibular autograft
Curettage, application of liquid nitrogen and polymethylmethacrylate

questions.text: A 32-year-old female presents with swelling and pain in the right wrist. The symptoms have progressed over the last 6 months and she has noted a decreased range of motion of the wrist joint. Figures A and B shows the histology. What is the best treatment option for this patient?
questions.solution:
• The patient is presenting with a giant cell tumor(GCT) of the right distal radius with preservation of the cortices and joint line. The best treatment option would be extensive curettage with adjuvant liquid nitrogen and polymethylmethacrylate(PMMA).
  • GCT is a common benign bone tumor that has some malignant characteristics. Approximately 5% of patients have metastasis to the lungs, which should prompt routine chest radiographs.
  • Surgical treatment usually involves extensive curettage with local adjuvant therapy, which includes liquid nitrogen, phenol, argon beam and PMMA. Utilizing PMMA had the added benefit of being employed with other local adjuvants prior to placement, as well as the potential to reveal any local recurrence as a lytic lesion at the bone-cement interface.

Reference: Maheshwari, Essentials Ortho, 5th edition, Page no. 239.

questions.text: An 8-years old boy presents with swelling in mid-thigh region. On examination, femoral thickening was found with Codman's triangle. On aspiration, greyish white liquid was aspirated that showed atypical round cells with MIC-2 positivity. The most likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis of a swelling in mid-thigh region of an 8-years old boy, with femoral thickening with greyish white liquid aspirated from swelling showing atypical round cells with MIC-2 positivity is Ewing's sarcoma.

Ewing's sarcoma: A type of primitive neuroectodermal tumour(PNET) On histopathological examination shows small round cells, which show positive immunohistochemical staining or CD-99 and MIC-2 gene. Although the classical periosteal reaction seen in Ewing's sarcoma is onion peel appearance but sometimes it can present as Codman's triangle.

Ewing's Sarcoma:

  • Arises from endothelial cells of the bone marrow in the diaphysis(medullary cavity) of long tubular bones(especially femur) and flat bones of pelvis.
  • Highly malignant, undifferentiated peripheral primitive neuroectodermal tumor(PNET)
  • MC site: Diaphysis of femur> fibula> ilium> tibia.
  • Pathology: Arising in medullar cavity usually invade the cortex and periosteum producing a soft tissue mass. Composed of sheets of uniform, small round cells(that are slightly larger than lymphocytes), with pale clear appearing cytoplasm due to presence of glycogen.
  • Cytoplasm is PAS positive and diastase digestible.
  • Presence of Homer-Wright rosettes and pseudo rosette is indicative of neural differentiation(i.e., PNET) Express MIC 2 gene in very high amount, distinguish from other round cell tumors
  • Most definitive test: Demonstration of chromosomal translocation by karyotyping or RT PCR DETECTION OF t(11:22)
  • 80%-90% patient have translocation mostly t(11:22)>t(21:22) and rarely t(7:22).
  • Ewing sarcomas are periodic acid Schiff positive(owing to intracellular glycogen) and reticulin negative.

Clinical Feature: Mostly in males between 10-20 years of age. Pain, swelling, tenderness, urinary/rectal complaints (when ilium involved) pathological fracture. Systemic symptoms such as fever, generalized weakness, weight loss and lab anomalies as anaemia, leukocytosis and raised ESR are hallmark of fulminating course, advanced disease or metastasis.

50% of all metastases occurs to lung and 25% to bone and bone marrow.

Diagnosis: Mottled rarefaction of spongiosa with permeation of overlying cortex, reflecting rapid bone destruction is the principal finding Laminated(layered) periosteal new bone formation known as onion-peel appearance soft tissue mass, indicating neoplasm has perforated cortex

Treatment: Highly radiosensitive(melts on radiotherapy) but overall survival is not much enhanced Chemotherapy is much more effective and include vincristine, actinomycin D, adriamycin, ifosfamide and etoposide. Best results are achieved by: Preoperative chemotherapy then wide excision(or amputation) if tumor is in favorable site and further chemotherapy for 1 years. Radiotherapy followed by local excision if it is in less accessible site and then further chemotherapy for 1 year.

Reference: Maheshwari, Essentials Ortho, 5th edition, Page no. 243.

questions.text: A 2 year old orphan child in brought by caregivers with history of fall from bed. He has spiral fracture of right femur and multiple rib fracture on left side. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• This is a case of Battered baby syndrome.
  • Reasons
    • The child is an orphan under care givers, which is a high risk for battered baby syndrome
    • There is a mismatch between the history and findings. It is unlikely that a simple fall from bed can cause so many fractures.
    • Spiral fracture of femur in small children usually occur when someone twists the leg.

Reference: Miler's 8th Edition of Review of Orthopaedics, page no. 2106

questions.text: An 18 years old male presents with a draining sinus on his left leg with pus discharge and discharge of bony pieces since in 3 months. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Chronic osteomyelitis:

  • Clinical features of chronic osteomyelitis
  • The commonest presenting symptom is a chronic discharging sinus. Pain is minimal or absent
  • Generalized symptoms of acute osteomyelitis are not present except in acute exacerbations.
  • On examination there is irregular thickening of bone
  • Mild tenderness may be seen in deep palpation
  • Adjacent joint may be stiff.

Radiological features: Following are radiological features

  • Thickening and irregularity of the cortices.
  • Patchy sclerosis
  • Bone cavity: This is seen as an area of rarefaction surrounded by sclerosis.
  • Sequestrum: This appears denser than the surrounding normal bone because the decalcification which occurs in normal bone, does not occur in dead bone. Granulation tissue surrounding the sequestrum gives rise to a radiolucent zone around it. A sequestrum may be visible in soft tissue.
  • Involucrum and cloacae may be visible.

Reference: Bailey and Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter: 17, Pg: 260.

questions.text: A 6 year old child presented with discharging sinus for the last 3 months. Identify the labelled structure
questions.solution:
• The x ray shows severe chronic osteomyelitis of the humerus in a child. Unfortunately, the entire humerus of the child is dead and has become a sequestrum. However, there is new bone formation circumferentially around the sequestrum. This is the involucrum, which is the marked structure.

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page no. 172

questions.text: A 35 year old male sustains a Sunderland type III Axillary nerve injury. What will his nerve injury be classified as, under the Seddon's classification system?
questions.solution:
• The Seddon classification and its corresponding Sunderland classification is given in the table below.
  • Sunderland types II, III and IV come under 'axonotmesis' of Seddon's classification.

Reference: Miler's 8th Edition of Review of Orthopaedics, page no. 1532

questions.text: Sangeetha gave birth to her first child 2 days back. She was informed by the doctor that the delivery was difficult as the shoulder of the child was stuck in the birth canal. Now, she noticed that the baby was not moving his right upper limb very well and the arm was kept close to the body, the elbow was straight and fore arm was facing to the back. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The deformity being described here is adduction of shoulder, extension of elbow and pronation of forearm. This is what we call the 'waiter's tip deformity'.
  • This is classically seen in Erb's palsy.
  • Further more, the mother had a difficult labor with shoulder dystocia which is a risk factor for Erb's palsy.

Reference: Miler's 8th Edition of Review of Orthopaedics, page no. 547

questions.text: Identify the splint shown in the image
questions.solution:
• The splint shown in the image is Knuckle bender splint.
  • It is used in claw hand deformity seen in Ulnar N palsy.

Reference: J. Maheshwari's Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page no. 71

questions.text: A 24-year-old male, who regularly works out at a gym, complains of pain in the left hip while performing squats and lunges. O/E, there is limitation of abduction and internal rotation. On questioning further, he confesses to using anabolic steroids regularly. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Hip pain in a patient who is on steroids, must raise the suspicion of AVN of the femoral head. Further, in this patient, there is limitation of abduction and internal rotation, which points towards AVN
  • In, Avascular necrosis of the femoral head, there is softening of bone leading to collapse and deformation of femoral head, later resulting in osteoarthritis
  • Most cases are idiopathic
  • The risk factors include-
    • Trauma
    • Steroid use
    • Alcohol abuse
    • Antiretrovirals
    • Gaucher's disease
    • Caisson's disease
    • Sickle cell disease
    • Thrombophilia
    • Protein C deficiency
    • Protein S deficiency

  • Clinical features - Patients present with hip pain and limping. On examination, there will be limitation of abduction and internal rotation and sectoral sign will be positive.
  • MRI is the investigation of choice
  • X ray changes are delayed and will show 'Crescent sign'
  • Treatment includes-
    • Early stage - Core decompression
    • Late stages - Total hip replacement

Crescent sign

Reference: Essential Orthopaedics: Maheshwari & Mhaskar, 5th Edition, Page Number-318.
